conclusion: The problem involves two harmonic transverse waves propagating in opposite directions with the same speed (0.4 m/s) and amplitude (2 m). The wave sources are located at x = -0.2 m and x = 1.2 m.
The figure shows the two waves at t = 0, with particles P and Q at x = 0.2 m and x = 0.8 m just beginning to vibrate, and particle M at x = 0.5 m located at the equilibrium position.
To solve the problem, we need to determine the time at which the two waves meet.
The wavelength 位 is determined as the distance between points where the waves are in phase. From the figure, this distance is 1.2 m.
The period T is calculated using T = 位/v. Substituting 位 = 1.2 m and v = 0.4 m/s, T = 3 s.
The waves are in phase at x = 0.5 m (point M) at t = 0.
The time for the right-propagating wave to reach x = 0.5 m from x = -0.2 m is calculated as t1 = 0.5 m / 0.4 m/s = 1.25 s.
The time for the left-propagating wave to reach x = 0.5 m from x = 1.2 m is calculated as t2 = 1.7 m / 0.4 m/s = 4.25 s.
The time difference between the arrival of the two waves at x = 0.5 m is t2 - t1 = 4.25 s - 1.25 s = 3 s.
Since the time difference is exactly one period (T = 3 s), the waves will meet at t = 1.25 s.
The time at which the two waves meet is 1.25 s.
